text: <@UCGAK10LS> For what it's worth, I applaud your efforts. I think new models are rare, but they do happen. They are hard, fraught with "peril" if you will, but can really shake things up. I agree with you on going back to the fundamentals. I have often found my most paradigm shifting moves have been when I start to feel stuck in the mire of all the complexity. Life is complex, but mostly we tend to tack on artificial complexity. If you can step back and look at the fundamentals there is often a new model that is begging to get out of the problems space, but we were just too far down the path we started down to notice.

elements.text: For what it's worth, I applaud your efforts. I think new models are rare, but they do happen. They are hard, fraught with "peril" if you will, but can really shake things up. I agree with you on going back to the fundamentals. I have often found my most paradigm shifting moves have been when I start to feel stuck in the mire of all the complexity. Life is complex, but mostly we tend to tack on artificial complexity. If you can step back and look at the fundamentals there is often a new model that is begging to get out of the problems space, but we were just too far down the path we started down to notice.

text: Personally, I'm more interested in the future of programming as a way to find new models or rediscover new usefulness in old models. I'm personally not so interested in the new cool toys, but prefer the more fundamental type stuff. That said, I do often find that insight comes from criticism. Someone will say something to me that doesn't sit right but I can't immediately explain why. In the end, if I can really dive into that critique there is something waiting for me to discover it there. At any rate, I hope you take any criticism from my end as me trying to help move toward an answer rather than stop or slow you down or a belief that you won't be successful.

elements.text: Personally, I'm more interested in the future of programming as a way to find new models or rediscover new usefulness in old models. I'm personally not so interested in the new cool toys, but prefer the more fundamental type stuff. That said, I do often find that insight comes from criticism. Someone will say something to me that doesn't sit right but I can't immediately explain why. In the end, if I can really dive into that critique there is something waiting for me to discover it there. At any rate, I hope you take any criticism from my end as me trying to help move toward an answer rather than stop or slow you down or a belief that you won't be successful.

text: Truthfully, I'm also attempting to develop a new model for programming by going back to the fundamentals of how processors work and seeing if we can go back to an early time and branch in a different direction than the one we took to get where we are today. Who knows if I'm going to be successful in developing anything relevant or useful but I'm trying my best anyway.

elements.text: Truthfully, I'm also attempting to develop a new model for programming by going back to the fundamentals of how processors work and seeing if we can go back to an early time and branch in a different direction than the one we took to get where we are today. Who knows if I'm going to be successful in developing anything relevant or useful but I'm trying my best anyway.

text: <@UCGAK10LS> is there somewhere I can go to read more about what you are trying to do?

elements.text: is there somewhere I can go to read more about what you are trying to do?

text: Yeah, I agree that constructive criticism can be helpful. In fact, I'm my own biggest critic. I keep tearing down my plans and prototypes as rubbish (because they are), and every time I do, I learn a little more. Those past failures led me to beliefs such as "graphs are neither the right interface, nor a helpful underlying model", upon which I base a lot of the assertions I make. Feedback from others is important too: hence I enjoy starting all these conversations here.

elements.text: Yeah, I agree that constructive criticism can be helpful. In fact, I'm my own biggest critic. I keep tearing down my plans and prototypes as rubbish (because they are), and every time I do, I learn a little more. Those past failures led me to beliefs such as "graphs are neither the right interface, nor a helpful underlying model", upon which I base a lot of the assertions I make. Feedback from others is important too: hence I enjoy starting all these conversations here.

text: <@U015902ESJC> Hardware design sounds 100x harder than PL design. Intel and AMD have armies of people whose career is exactly that :grimacing:, though yes, with strong biases towards incrementalism.

elements.text: Hardware design sounds 100x harder than PL design. Intel and AMD have armies of people whose career is exactly that
, though yes, with strong biases towards incrementalism.

text: <@U015902ESJC> Unfortunately when people ask me this, the answer is no. There is no good place to read about what I'm doing. The reason? As mentioned above, aspects of my plan and vision keep churning significantly. I don't have a story I'm willing to commit to yet. But I'm working towards it!

elements.text: Unfortunately when people ask me this, the answer is no. There is no good place to read about what I'm doing. The reason? As mentioned above, aspects of my plan and vision keep churning significantly. I don't have a story I'm willing to commit to yet. But I'm working towards it!

text: My goal is pretty easy to state though: I'm trying to vastly simplify software development. I want to make it 100x simpler. I want to find the simplest programming model & infrastructure that can possibly exist. I've not been willing to make any compromises on that quest.

elements.text: My goal is pretty easy to state though: I'm trying to vastly simplify software development. I want to make it 100x simpler. I want to find the simplest programming model & infrastructure that can possibly exist. I've not been willing to make any compromises on that quest.

text: And unlike with projects like "Scratch", I don't think simplicity entails coming up with a cute cat avatar and adding lots of colours to the IDE. :confused:

elements.text: And unlike with projects like "Scratch", I don't think simplicity entails coming up with a cute cat avatar and adding lots of colours to the IDE.

text: Though of course, the Scratch people would probably argue their goal is "onboarding", not discovering new simplicity.

elements.text: Though of course, the Scratch people would probably argue their goal is "onboarding", not discovering new simplicity.

text: I will know I've succeeded if children and experienced developers both use the same interface.

elements.text: I will know I've succeeded if children and experienced developers both use the same interface.

text: <@UC2A2ARPT> has renamed the channel from "general" to "thinking-together"
name: thinking-together

text: Interesting wrinkle — when you use the #hashtag name for a channel in a message, and then rename the channel, your message is updated to reflect the new name. Most curious, and likely carries a number of second order consequences.

elements.text: Interesting wrinkle — when you use the #hashtag name for a channel in a message, and then rename the channel, your message is updated to reflect the new name. Most curious, and likely carries a number of second order consequences.

text:
The traffic jam would be everyone is flinging code like everyone is now a writer... in the micro-form of posts and tweets, that are now swamping the earth

I think a lot about the micro-form of coding that people use to amuse themselves and get something small done - maybe if it’s done right, there‘ll be less writing/venting out in the world and more getting results

text: I could have changed it to anything — I just wanted to see what happened to my message (where the text `#share-your-work` wasn't an automatic channel link). But just in case Slack had some sort of dumb limit about naming channels back to the names they previously had, I went with something I'd have been happy with if we were to end up stuck with it.

text:
*Welcome to <#C5T9GPWFL|thinking-together>!*

This is the new channel for discussions based on our own thoughts and questions about the future of computing.

• While you can add reference links to your posts, please take any discussions that center around external links to <#C5U3SEW6A|linking-together> 
• While you can discuss the future in light of the present, please take any discussions that are mostly about computing (or the world) of today to <#C01932BJGE8|present-company>
• If you'd like to discuss your own work, (A) please do that a lot it's great I love it (B) over in <#CCL5VVBAN|share-your-work>
• If you'd like to discuss the future of a particular subject, don't miss our subject-specific channels about the future <#CLYCGTCPL|of-end-user-programming>, <#CE1R695T7|of-graphics>, <#C0133ED5811|of-functional-programming>, and <#CEZ6QTHL1|of-music>.
I am working on a new Member's Handbook that will be the canonical home for our cultural norms (how we use Slack messages, the channels, etc) — so stay tuned for that if you aren't quite sure about how to make the most of the new organizational scheme.

One final note — I attempted to add everyone in the Slack to <#CGMJ7323Z|announcements> and <#C01932BJGE8|present-company>, but the Slack UI for this is not great. I know for certain I didn't get everyone, and I can't easily tell who I missed, so if you aren't in those channels then I encourage you to join them.
